description: From Middle English upon, uppon, uppen, from Old English upon, uppon, uppan (“on, upon, up to, against, after, in addition to”), equivalent to up (“adverb”) +‎ on (“preposition”). Cognate with Icelandic upp á, upp á (“up on, upon”), Swedish på (“up on, upon”), Danish på (“up on, upon”), Norwegian på (“up on, upon”).

entries.meaning: Physically above and in contact with.
examples: Place the book upon the table.
The crew set sail upon the sea.

entries.meaning: Being followed by another so as to form a series.
examples: hours upon hours, years upon years, mile upon mile of desert
The contract was rendered void upon his death.
Little disappointed, then, she turned attention to "Chat of the Social World," gossip which exercised potent fascination upon the girl's intelligence.
